Graphical abstract This review systematically details how magnetic fields enhance oxygen electrocatalysis via gas management engineering and reaction rate acceleration. Magnetic fields offer a non-invasive strategy to modulate oxygen electrocatalysis, but a clear and unified understanding of the underlying mechanisms still remains challenging. This review provides a systematic classification of magneto-electrocatalytic effects, including gas management engineering and reaction rate acceleration, and summarizes the latest research advancements in the field. In addition, this review offers a critical evaluation of prevailing mechanistic theories. Specifically, we highlight the inability of the magnetoresistance effect to account for the pronounced pH dependency of magnetic enhancement. Furthermore, we discuss in depth the ongoing debate surrounding the electron spin selectivity effect, questioning its universal validity. We also emphasize some key breakthroughs, particularly the relationship between domain wall elimination and enhanced catalytic activity. This review also addresses the critical experimental challenges of decoupling coexisting magnetic effects, emphasizing the necessary experimental procedures designed to distinguish macroscopic, magnetohydrodynamic-driven convection from intrinsic, spin-mediated kinetic enhancements. Finally, the future progresses are proposed, hinging on the strategic integration of magnetic fields with other external fields, like electric, photonic, or thermal fields, to unlock the novel catalytic pathways and precisely steer reaction selectivity and efficiency. Keywords Magnetic field Oxygen electrocatalysis Mass transport Reaction kinetic 1 Introduction Oxygen electrocatalysis, as an efficient energy conversion pathway, plays an increasingly vital role in addressing the current energy crisis and environmental challenges [1–3]. Advancements in electrocatalysis offer sustainable and feasible solutions, particularly in critical areas such as hydrogen production [4–6], fuel cells [7–9], metal-air batteries [10–13], and wastewater treatment [14–16]. Electrocatalytic techniques are primarily employed because certain electrochemical reactions exhibit sluggish kinetics under conventional conditions and are therefore unlikely to proceed spontaneously. Among these reactions, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are particularly prominent [17–19]. For instance, during the operation of water electrolysers and fuel cells, the kinetic rates of oxygen electrocatalytic reactions (ORR/OER) are significantly lower than those of hydrogen electrocatalytic reactions (hydrogen evolution reaction/hydrogen oxidation reaction), owing to the four-electron nature of the ORR/OER, which requires at least four elementary steps from reactants to products, further compounded by the triplet state of O2 that impedes reaction progress [20,21]. In contrast, hydrogen electrocatalytic reactions, being two-electron processes, proceed relatively more readily [22–24]. Consequently, over the past few decades, numerous electrocatalysts with acceptable performance have been developed for oxygen electrocatalysis; among these materials, transition metal-based catalysts—such as Fe-based [25,26], Co-based [27,28], Ni-based [4,29,30], and Mn-based catalysts [31,32]—are the most prominent due to their cost-effectiveness and catalytic efficiency. To enhance the performance of these electrocatalysts, researchers have adopted various strategies, including doping modification, morphology control, and compositional tuning. Regrettably, most research findings have not developed beyond the laboratory stage, with industrial-scale production remaining unfeasible as their electrocatalytic properties (e.g., activity, stability, and poisoning resistance) fall short of commercial application requirements [33]. Thus, regulating the electrocatalytic process from a broader perspective, particularly with respect to the influence of external conditions on catalyst performance, has emerged as a new focal point for researchers [34,35]. As non-contact and tuneable external fields, magnetic fields can influence electrocatalytic reactions in a non-invasive manner, modulating not only mass transport and ion distribution in the electrolyte [36] but also the electronic and spin states at the electrocatalyst surface, thereby affecting reaction pathways and kinetic processes [37]. Magnetic fields can induce electron spin polarization, facilitating the formation of specific electron spin states, which reduces the activation energy of the reaction and enhances catalyst activity and selectivity [38]. In addition to their direct effects on the electrocatalyst, magnetic fields exert Lorentz forces on moving charged particles within the electrolyte of the reaction system. The accelerated motion of these charged ions generates magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) flow, further promoting efficient bubble detachment from the electrode surface, thereby enhancing mass transport and electrocatalytic efficiency [39]. Additionally, magnetic fields can influence the motion of charged particles in solution via MHD effect, thereby augmenting mass transport within the electrolyte [40]. Specifically, magnetic fields generate Lorentz forces on charged particles (e.g., ions) in the electrolyte, inducing solution flow (convection) and increasing the mixing and diffusion rates of solutes. The enhanced mass transport of reactants and rapid detachment of products from the reaction surface improve the electrocatalytic performance of the ORR and OER, respectively. Furthermore, the application of magnetic fields can promote dynamic adsorption/desorption equilibrium at the electrocatalyst surface, accelerating the conversion of reaction intermediates and increasing reaction rates. Under certain conditions, magnetic fields can also provide additional localized heating via magnetothermal effects, supplying energy to the reaction and further enhancing electrocatalytic performance [55]. However, fully harnessing the advantages of magnetic field-enhanced electrocatalysis requires a deeper understanding of the mechanisms by which magnetic fields influence electrocatalytic reactions. These considerations encompass not only the effects of magnetic fields on the electrolyte, electrode materials, and electrocatalytic interfaces but also complex factors such as the field strength, direction, distribution and their interactions with the electrocatalytic system. To clarify these underlying mechanisms, a holistic approach is required to assess the interactions among electrocatalysts, external fields, and reaction systems, integrating interdisciplinary insights from chemistry, physics, materials science, and mechanical design to systematically understand and leverage the mechanisms of magnetic field effects on electrocatalytic reactions and ultimately develop more efficient and innovative electrocatalytic technologies. To date, no comprehensive and detailed review of the field of magnetic field-enhanced oxygen electrocatalysis has been published. However, in recent years, several milestone studies have emerged, significantly advancing our understanding of magnetic field effects on oxygen electrocatalysis (Fig. 1 ). Notably, the past two years have witnessed major breakthroughs in identifying the sources of magnetic field enhancement in both ferromagnetic and non-magnetic materials. These advancements have substantially addressed a critical gap in the research on magnetic field effects on electrocatalysis, paving the way for future exploration. The study of magnetic field effects on catalysis is likely to emerge as a prominent research area in the coming years. This review aims to provide a comprehensive review of the fundamental theories and application advancements in magnetic field-enhanced oxygen electrocatalysis (Fig. 2 ). This review explores the various mechanisms through which magnetic fields enhance the efficiency and selectivity of electrocatalytic reactions and evaluates the potential of this process in future energy conversion applications. Although the mechanisms by which magnetic fields influence oxygen electrocatalysis are diverse, the ultimate effects primarily manifest as enhanced mass transport within the reaction system and improved reaction rate. We contend that, with deeper investigations into the mechanisms of magnetic field-enhanced electrocatalysis and continuous technological optimization, this field will yield novel breakthroughs, significantly contributing to the development of sustainable energy technologies. 2 Categories of magnetic fields 2.1 External magnetic field The influence of magnetic fields on oxygen electrocatalysis can be categorized into two sources: internal and external magnetic fields. External magnetic fields typically refer to those applied to an electrocatalytic system via external devices, such as permanent magnets, electromagnets, or energized coils. The kinetics of electrocatalytic reactions can be optimized by adjusting the strength, direction, and distribution of these magnetic fields, thereby enhancing catalyst activity, stability, and selectivity. 2.1.1 Uniform magnetic field A uniform magnetic field is defined as one in which the magnetic induction strength (magnetic flux density) remains constant in magnitude and direction across all points in space. In a uniform magnetic field, magnetic field lines are distributed in parallel without bending or converging, indicating that the field strength remains constant at any given point. As illustrated in Fig. 3 a, an approximately uniform magnetic field forms in the central region between two parallel magnetic poles [54]. Under these conditions, the magnetic field lines are both parallel and equidistant. Charged particles in a uniform magnetic field experience a Lorentz force that is stable in both direction and magnitude, allowing their motion trajectories to be predicted. Compared with gradient magnetic fields, uniform magnetic fields exert a consistent attractive force on magnetic materials irrespective of position and are therefore suitable for precisely controlling specific reactions or motion processes. Uniform magnetic fields are typically generated by electromagnets (e.g., through specifically arranged coils), whose strength and direction can be precisely and conveniently adjusted via the supply current, facilitating mechanistic studies of magnetic field effects in electrocatalytic reactions [56]. 2.1.2 Non-uniform magnetic field A non-uniform magnetic field is characterized by a magnetic induction strength (B) that varies across different spatial positions, meaning that its magnitude or direction is not constant, exhibiting a spatial gradient (∇B ≠ 0). In contrast to uniform magnetic fields, the magnetic field lines in a non-uniform magnetic field typically converge or diverge, resulting in varying field strengths and directions across different regions. The magnetic field gradient exerts additional forces on paramagnetic or diamagnetic substances, driving their motion along the gradient direction [57]. Non-uniform magnetic fields induce Kelvin forces on paramagnetic O2, enhancing its transport [58] and improving the kinetic performance of the ORR and OER. Through external non-uniform magnetic fields, the diffusion pathways of O2 can be controlled, facilitating its access to catalytic active sites, reducing mass transport polarization, and enhancing the ORR efficiency at fuel cell cathodes. To introduce non-uniform magnetic fields in metal–air batteries, one approach involves placing a permanent magnet directly on two sides of the battery (Fig. 3b) [59], creating a gradient in magnetic field strength within the battery; however, this technique is often limited by the low field strength (tens to hundreds of mT), rendering the resultant Kelvin force insufficient to significantly impact the reaction. 2.1.3 Alternating magnetic field An alternating magnetic field (AMF) is defined as a magnetic field whose strength and direction vary periodically with time. Unlike static magnetic fields, AMFs are characterized by temporal variability, enabling distinct system effects through frequency modulation [51]. Under the influence of an AMF, magnetic moments in materials undergo periodic “switching” as the field oscillates, a process that consumes energy [51,60]. According to thermodynamic principles, this energy is converted into heat, constituting the core mechanism of the magnetothermal effect. As shown in Fig. 3c, a high-frequency AMF acting on magnetic nanoparticles induces localized temperature increases through effects such as hysteresis loss or eddy current heating [51,61,62]. The generated heat can elevate the localized temperature required for electrocatalytic reactions, thereby enhancing the reaction rate. Particularly in the ORR and OER, a moderate temperature increase can effectively lower the reaction energy barrier, accelerate electron transfer, and improve catalytic efficiency. However, how to control the magnitude of the temperature increase to avoid adversely affecting catalyst stability still requires further experimental and theoretical investigations. Additionally, AMFs may enhance electrocatalytic activity by altering the electron spin states at the catalyst surface, optimizing electron transfer processes, particularly in paramagnetic or ferromagnetic catalysts, where spin polarization regulation accelerates electron transfer [55]. 2.2 Internal magnetic field During electrocatalytic reaction testing, external magnetic field configurations are simple and cost effective; however, as implementation of these fields requires additional battery components, they increase the device volume and may compromise battery integration. To address this issue, researchers have explored the use of internal magnetic fields to enhance battery performance. One approach to achieving internal magnetic fields involves embedding minute magnetic materials, which do not directly participate in electrochemical reactions, into the battery electrodes (Fig. 3d). Shi et al. [64] successfully prepared magnetic electrode materials by incorporating Nd2Fe14B magnetic powder into electrodes, followed by high-temperature demagnetization and microwave sintering. This method not only generates a minute magnetic field within metal–air batteries to optimize the reaction conditions but also reduces the spatial requirements compared with of external magnetic field setups. Furthermore, the loading density of magnetic materials can be adjusted to control the magnetic field strength. Another method leverages the inherent magnetism of transition metal oxides to fabricate magnetic electrode materials. Okada et al. [57] demonstrated that embedding Nd/Fe/B magnetic particles directly into a cathode catalyst, followed by magnetization with an external magnetic field, effectively enhances battery performance, particularly in the limiting current region. Compared with external magnetic field generation, internal magnetic field generation is less controllable and exhibits some randomness; however, researchers have overcome this limitation by adjusting particle alignment or utilizing external fields. Studies have indicated that minute internal magnetic field can optimize the ORR process within batteries, particularly at the rate-determining step, thereby enhancing overall battery performance [65]. However, the strategy of using embedded magnetic materials, while intriguing, raises significant concerns regarding their practical long-term application. Long-term stability is the primary issue. The direct contact with often aggressive electrolytes poses a major threat, particularly for materials like NdFeB magnets [66]. These are notoriously susceptible to chemical attack; in acidic electrolytes, they undergo rapid dissolution, and even in alkaline electrolytes, their neodymium-rich grain boundaries remain highly reactive. This degradation process has a dual negative effect: it causes a loss of magnetic properties over time, and more importantly, the leached metal ions could potentially adsorb onto the active sites of the primary electrocatalyst, leading to severe catalyst poisoning and a continuous decline in performance [67]. Consequently, any embedded magnet would require a robust, highly dense and uniform protective coating, as any defects could lead to localized corrosion and eventual failure. This adds significant complexity and cost to electrode fabrication. Furthermore, the intimate mixing of these magnetic particles with the catalyst and conductive additives within the electrode matrix makes their subsequent separation and recyclability exceedingly difficult, especially for those containing valuable rare-earth elements. 3 Mechanism of magnetic field-enhanced oxygen electrocatalytic reactions The potential mechanisms by which magnetic fields enhance electrocatalytic reactions are currently categorized as follows: 1) the MHD effect, 2) the Kelvin force effect, 3) the electron spin selectivity effect, 4) the electron spin alignment effect, 5) the Maxwell stress effect, and 6) the magnetothermal effect. This section presents the specific explanations of how these effects influence electrocatalytic reaction systems. Notably, whether under a static magnetic field or an AMF, multiple effects often function synergistically within a single electrocatalytic process, with their mutual interactions further accelerating the reaction. Although electrocatalytic reactions affected by magnetic fields are governed by numerous mechanisms, the primary influence of the magnetic field on oxygen electrocatalysis is manifested in the adsorption and desorption of oxygen species on the catalyst sites and the management of reactants/products. Accordingly, based on this dual classification, the MHD effect, Kelvin force effect, and Maxwell stress effect can be categorized as magnetic field-induced influences on catalyst surface gas management, while the electron spin selectivity effect, electron spin alignment effect, and magnetothermal effect can be classified as magnetic field-induced influences on reaction rate. These influence mechanisms will be elaborated upon in detail below. 3.1 Lorentz force and MHD effect The factors influencing electrocatalytic reaction rates include not only the inherent catalytic activity of the electrocatalyst but also the transport and detachment of reactants and products at the catalyst surface [68,69]. Currently, stirring or gas diffusion electrodes are primarily employed to enhance mass transport during the reaction process. Studies indicate that the MHD effect can serve as an alternative to these mass transport methods [36,70–72]. In electrocatalytic reactions, current typically flows through the electrode, implying the presence of moving charges. When a magnetic field is applied to such an electrochemical system, the moving charged particles (e.g., ions or electrons) experience a Lorentz force, altering their motion path from linear to helical. The Lorentz force is determined by Eq. (1) [73–75] (1) F L = B j The direction of the Lorentz force is perpendicular to both the velocity of the charged particle and the magnetic field, as determined by the left-hand rule. The magnitude of the Lorentz force is proportional to the product of current density and magnetic field strength, and it depends on the angle between the current and magnetic field directions [73]. As depicted in Fig. 4 a–c, the Lorentz force reaches its maximum when the current direction is perpendicular to the magnetic field, and it becomes zero when the current and field directions are parallel or antiparallel. However, the Lorentz force is not always beneficial; as shown in Fig. 4e, when its direction opposes buoyancy and hinders diffusion, it impedes bubble removal, whereas alignment with buoyancy facilitates diffusion [76]. As shown in Fig. 4f, when the Lorentz force is upward, the bubbles exhibit a spiraling rise to the top of the page; when the Lorentz force is downward, it extends the bubbles' residence time on the electrode surfaces [77]. Furthermore, while moderate Lorentz forces induce beneficial MHD convection, an excessive force, particularly at high current densities, can be detrimental. The resulting intense turbulence at the electrode surface can disrupt the stability of the electrode–electrolyte interface, potentially leading to mechanical damage or even the detachment of the catalyst layer from the substrate. When the electrode surface exhibits geometric irregularities or microscopic roughness, the current distribution across the surface becomes non-uniform. As illustrated in Fig. 4d, this non-uniform current distribution induces localized variations in the electric and magnetic fields near the electrode surface, generating distinct flow patterns and consequently micro-MHD vortices [73]. Experiments have demonstrated that the micro-MHD effect promotes bubble release [69]. However, other studies suggest that the micro-MHD effect may increase the bubble rupture radius, thereby stabilizing bubbles at the electrode surface [37]. Consequently, further in-depth research into the mechanisms and directional micro-MHD effect on bubbles is warranted, particularly regarding the interactions among bubbles at the electrode surface. In addition to guiding liquid flow and facilitating bubble removal, the MHD effect also enhances ion diffusion and convection in the electrolyte, thereby improving mass transport within the reaction system. Specifically, in oxygen electrocatalytic reaction processes, ionic currents in the ORR and OER arise from the directional transport of charged reactants and products within the double-layer region. During the reaction, multiple processes involving ions and electrons occur, with ion adsorption and desorption taking place in the double-layer region at the electrode surface. When the applied magnetic field is perpendicular to the direction of ion motion, the instantaneous force experienced by charged particles can be expressed using the generalized Langevin form of the Lorentz force, as follows [68,78] (2) F → t = q ( E → + v → ( t ) × B → ) - ∫ 0 t γ t - t ′ v → t ′ d t ′ + ξ → ( t ) Here, ∫ 0 t γ t - t ′ v → t ′ d t ′ represents the frictional resistance to ion motion, while ξ → ( t ) denotes a random force arising from collisions with solvent molecules. Equation (2) predicts that charged particles in solution experience a force along the electric field direction, a force perpendicular to both the particle velocity and the magnetic field, and field-independent frictional and random forces due to solvent molecule collisions. These frictional interactions mediate the application of the Lorentz force to ions, converting it into hydrodynamic flow within the fluid at the electrode surface. This results in a significant increase in the concentration gradient within the diffusion double layer, reducing its thickness compared with scenarios without a magnetic field [79,80], ultimately enhancing the diffusion rate of reactants towards the electrode surface (Fig. 4g). As evidenced by the particle image velocimetry (PIV) maps in Fig. 4h, under a magnetic field, the electrolyte at the electrode surface exhibits high-speed rotational flow, driven by Lorentz force-induced MHD vortices. This forced convection further disrupts the stagnant boundary layer and homogenizes the reactant distribution. The role of the magnetic field is also critically dependent on its orientation (B) relative to the electrode surface and the ionic current (j), as this parameter fundamentally dictates which physical effects will dominate. When the magnetic field is applied perpendicular to the direction of ionic current (j⊥B), migrating charged species in the electrolyte experience a maximal Lorentz force [40,56]. This force induces a strong MHD convection, which enhances mass transport by stirring the bulk fluid. For gas-evolving reactions, such as the OER, direct visualization using a transparent electrode has demonstrated that this MHD convection effectively “flushes away” O2 bubbles, significantly reducing electrode surface coverage. The primary driver for this entire process is the Lorentz force acting directly on the migrating ions. The observed movement of gas bubbles, therefore, is a consequential effect of the fluid convection driven by this primary ionic movement, rather than a direct interaction between the bubbles and the magnetic field itself. Conversely, when the field is applied parallel to the ionic current (j||B), the Lorentz force and the macroscopic MHD effect are minimized [40,54]. This configuration is therefore ideal for isolating and studying more subtle, non-MHD-related phenomena, such as intrinsic kinetic and spin-related effects at the interface. It is important to note that a field applied parallel to the electrode surface can still induce a local surface-MHD effect by acting on the near-surface current (I s) flowing perpendicularly towards it, which helps carry oxygen to more active regions [56]. In fact, systematic research of these orientational effects in the ORR has revealed that the greatest enhancement (∼60 %) occurs when the field is perpendicular to both the bulk (I b) and surface (I s) currents, confirming a powerful synergistic effect between bulk and surface MHD flows [40]. In summary, the orientation of the magnetic field is a critical experimental design choice: a perpendicular arrangement (j⊥B) is a proven method to enhance mass transport, while a parallel arrangement (j||B) is essential for minimizing MHD interference to probe fundamental spin-related and interfacial kinetics. 3.2 Kelvin force effect Unlike the Lorentz force, which acts on charged species, the Kelvin force typically influences paramagnetic substances in electrocatalytic reaction systems [81]. Under a non-uniform magnetic field, or in the presence of a magnetic field gradient, the Kelvin force is superimposed on the motion of paramagnetic substances in the solution, thereby affecting electrochemical reaction processes at the electrode; hence, this force is also referred to as the magnetic gradient force. The magnitude of the Kelvin force is positively correlated with the magnetic field strength, its gradient, and the concentration of magnetic substances [82,83], as expressed by (3) F K = ( 1 2 μ 0 ) c χ m ∇ B 2 Here, μ 0 is the magnetic constant (4π × 10−7 H·m−1), c is the concentration of magnetic substances, χ m is the molar magnetic susceptibility, and ∇ B is the gradient of magnetic induction strength. In a non-uniform magnetic field, a stronger field generates a greater Kelvin force, attracting paramagnetic substances towards regions of increasing field strength, whereas diamagnetic substances are drawn towards regions of decreasing field strength [41]. The Kelvin force in non-uniform magnetic fields impacts electrocatalytic activity, particularly with respect to paramagnetic substances such as O2. It accelerates the mass transport of paramagnetic materials, enhances reaction rates near the electrode, thins the diffusion layer, and increases the limiting current [84,85]. Furthermore, studies indicate that paramagnetic gases are attracted towards regions with higher magnetic field strength [41], a phenomenon that enhances the ORR rate in energy conversion devices. In metal–air batteries and certain fuel cells, air is often the cathode reactant. However, various air components and generated water can occupy active sites on the catalyst surface, impeding O2 reduction and resulting in concentration polarization, thereby reducing current density and battery power. The Kelvin force attracts paramagnetic O2 to the electrode, achieving O2 enrichment, mitigating the “congestion” of diamagnetic nitrogen or water at the surface, and providing additional O2 transport pathways [86]. 3.3 Maxwell stress effect Maxwell stress arises from the interaction between a magnetic field and the dipole moments of components [87] and describes the distribution of electromagnetic forces within a medium. Although a uniform magnetic field may exert no net magnetic force across a concentration gradient, the Maxwell stress tensor accounts for internal stresses within the system induced by electromagnetic fields. This tensor is expressed by the following equation [88,89] (4) T ij = ε E i E j + 1 μ B i B j - 1 2 ε E 2 + 1 μ B 2 δ ij Here, ε denotes the material’s dielectric constant, μ is the magnetic permeability, and δ ij is the Kronecker delta. Maxwell stress exerts a tensile force along the magnetic field direction on charged particles or magnetized regions within droplets, causing paramagnetic droplets to elongate and alter their shape, as illustrated in Fig. 5 a [90,91]. This effect is observable in both conductive and magnetized droplets, with the degree of elongation dependent on the magnetic field strength and droplet properties (Fig. 5b), consequently modifying characteristics such as curvature and wettability [92,93]. In systems where a paramagnetic liquid phase is surrounded by a diamagnetic medium, the stress induced by the magnetic field produces distinct mechanical effects depending on the field’s orientation relative to the electrode: when parallel to the electrode, the stress causes stretching and elongation of the paramagnetic phase; when perpendicular, it results in compression (Fig. 5c) [90,91]. This phenomenon is particularly pronounced in ferrofluids, where spherical droplets undergo significant deformation upon magnetic field application, demonstrating the influence of electromagnetic stress (Fig. 5d). Research indicated that magnetic fields apply Maxwell stress to paramagnetic radicals near the electrode, displacing the outer Helmholtz plane and thereby influencing the electrochemical interface (Fig. 5e) [94]. Moreover, applying a magnetic field parallel to the electrode surface, concurrent with the reversible single-electron reduction of NB, suppressed the double-layer capacitance and increased the charge transfer resistance (Fig. 5f). Although Maxwell stress theoretically affects the electrode/electrolyte interface distribution, no examples of its use to enhance oxygen electrocatalysis have been reported to date. 3.4 Electron spin selectivity effect Beyond the gas management engineering discussed previously, magnetic fields can profoundly influence the intrinsic reaction rate by interacting with the electron spin, a quantum mechanical property central to the OER and ORR. The reaction mechanisms of OER and ORR involve a four-electron process, wherein the transformation between singlet state reactants (e.g., OH−/H2O) and the triplet state product (O2) proceeds via several oxygen intermediates (∗OH, ∗O, ∗OOH, and ∗ OO ∗ ), accompanied by mutual spin state transitions [95–98]. This required change in the system's total spin state imposes a kinetic barrier according to spin conservation rules. For instance, during the OER process, a catalyst must efficiently extract three electrons of one spin orientation and one of the opposite spin (Fig. 6 a). Failing to do so necessitates an energetically costly spin-flip event (Fig. 6b). Based on the same principle, during the ORR process, the catalyst must supply three spin-down electrons and one spin-up electron to oxygen intermediates [95]. Spin-related catalysis aims to overcome this barrier by creating spin-selective pathways, which can arise from fundamentally different physical origins. One direct way to influence these spin-dependent reactions is by using ferromagnetic (FM) catalysts. Due to intrinsic exchange interactions, FM materials possess spin-ordered domains that can act as natural “spin filters.” Recent studies have demonstrated that ferromagnetic materials can extract or transfer electrons with varying spin directions via spin-selective channels [99–102]. Under an applied magnetic field, the catalyst can function as a spin filter to regulate the spin distribution of intermediate radical electrons in electrocatalytic reactions, with oxygen-related radical states classified as singlet or triplet (Fig. 6c) [103], enabling selective radical recombination through magnetic field application [104]. The influence of this spin selectivity primarily encompasses transitions between electron states and spin flipping, which enhance the adsorption of intermediates on the catalyst surface, thereby optimizing reaction pathways and improving efficiency (Fig. 6e) [81,105,106]. Importantly, such spin-selective effects are not exclusive to magnetic materials. A distinct mechanism, known as the chirality-induced spin selectivity (CISS) effect, demonstrates that electron spin can be filtered by the geometry of a molecule rather than its magnetic order. In this effect, chiral molecules act as electron filters, permitting preferential spin orientations to pass through chiral materials, a concept initially proposed by Ray Krishanu [107]. Pioneering work by Naaman et al. experimentally verified this, showing that when electrodes are coated with non-magnetic chiral molecules, the overpotential for water splitting is dramatically reduced [108]. A theoretical framework that helps explain these diverse spin-dependent phenomena is the quantum spin exchange interaction (QSEI), notably refined by Gracia [50]. QSEI posits that interactions favoring parallel spins (ferromagnetic coupling) can reduce the Coulomb repulsion between electrons as they move through orbitals, thus lowering the energetic barrier for charge transport and catalysis (Fig. 6d). Gracia's framework is broad, and he proposed that in some complex oxides, “helimagnetic currents” arising from the crystal structure can produce a spin-valve effect “similar” to the CISS effect found in chiral molecules. Several studies have attempted to validate these hypotheses through theoretical calculations [105,109], yet researchers have been unable to directly substantiate these claims experimentally. Some studies suggest that applying a magnetic field alters the electron configuration of magnetic materials—such as through electron spin flipping or cation transitions from low- to high-spin states—which is theoretically plausible due to Zeeman splitting of electron energy levels under high-intensity magnetic fields, where energy levels shift with magnetic field components [110–112]. As shown in Fig. 6f, a magnetic field induces a transition in the electron spin configuration of Fe3O4@CNTs from low-spin to high-spin [38]. This modification leads to a significant increase in the OER catalytic activity of Fe3O4@CNTs (Fig. 6g). However, such electron configuration transitions typically require external magnetic fields exceeding tens of tesla [82,113,114], which is impractical in most application scenarios. Furthermore, while electron spin polarization is already achieved within magnetic domains, external magnetic fields should theoretically be ineffective in enhancing the oxygen electrocatalytic performance of magnetic materials. However, empirical evidence contradicts this supposition, and the electron spin alignment effect, discussed next, effectively explains this discrepancy. 3.5 Electron spin alignment effect Further examining the influence of magnetic fields on magnetic electrocatalysts, another potential mechanism by which magnetic fields enhance electrocatalytic reactions is the electron spin alignment effect. In ferromagnetic materials, internal atomic magnetic moments align in parallel due to exchange interactions, resulting in spontaneous magnetization [115,116], which persists without an external magnetic field (Fig. 7 a) and can be characterized via hysteresis loops (Fig. 7b). Consequently, the ordered electron spins in ferromagnetic materials can optimize exchange interactions among parallel spins, thereby improving the sluggish kinetics of oxygen electrocatalysis [50,117,118]. This relationship reveals an apparent contradiction: according to spin effect theory, once the catalyst’s electron spin state changes, sustained magnetic field application should theoretically be unnecessary, but upon field removal, the performance enhancement diminishes; thus, an explanation based on the changes in the magnetic material before and after external field application must be established [53]. As shown in Fig. 7c, in the absence of an external magnetic field, the domains in ferromagnetic materials are randomly arranged to minimize the system’s total energy, with the domain size and shape dependent on the material’s microstructure, temperature, and other external conditions [56]. By forming domains and allowing magnetic moments to cancel out across different regions, the system reduces its total energy. as the external magnetic field increases, the catalyst's magnetic domains align until the material reaches magnetic saturation. Any increase in field strength beyond this point provides no further catalytic benefit from spin polarization but only increases the system's energy cost. Applying a magnetic field does not readily increase spin polarization within individual domains [119]. The influence of a magnetic field on the net spin angular momentum of each unpaired electron (including those at active sites) is likely negligible, yet it can align all domains in a uniform direction and eliminate domain walls between them. Moreover, the enhancement of electrocatalytic performance due to magnetization does not derive from the spin flipping of unpaired electrons at the atomic level, which is infeasible. Instead, the determining factor is likely at a scale larger than the atomic level, namely, in the domains and the domain walls between them. Recent research has revealed that magnetic field-enhanced electrocatalysis originates from the disappearance of domain walls in transition metals, where domain walls constitute boundaries between adjacent magnetic domains [120]. Ren et al. reported a strong correlation between the domain wall area in transition metals and the enhancement of electrocatalytic performance [53]. They synthesized a series of materials with varying domain wall areas (Fig. 7d), compared their electrocatalytic performance under a magnetic field, and ultimately found that thicker domain walls correlate with more pronounced enhancements in the electrocatalytic performance of magnetic materials via magnetic fields. This study offers a novel perspective on the role of magnetic fields in electrocatalytic research. While these findings provide strong correlational evidence, direct in situ observation of these domain dynamics during electrocatalysis is crucial for cementing the mechanism. A recent pivotal study provided exactly this type of direct evidence using 2D Fe7Se8 nanosheets [121]. As shown in Fig. 7e, by integrating in situ magnetic force microscopy (MFM) with in situ Raman spectroscopy, they directly observed changes in surface spin configurations under an applied magnetic field and correlated them with OER activity. The in situ MFM results revealed that a 200 mT magnetic field effectively eliminated the spin-disordered domain walls present in the material, transforming the surface into a uniform, spin-ordered single-domain structure. Critically, the in situ Raman spectroscopy demonstrated the functional consequence of this change: the potential required to form the key FeOOH* intermediate was significantly lower (1.45 V) on the spin-ordered domain regions compared to the disordered domain walls (1.60 V). The electron spin alignment effect can be further validated by comparing the oxygen electrocatalytic performance of multi-domain and single-domain ferromagnetic catalysts with and without a magnetic field [52]. As demonstrated by Ge et al., single-domain catalysts, which possess ordered magnetic dipoles even without an external field, exhibit high intrinsic activity, while the activity of multi-domain catalysts can be enhanced to similar levels after their domains are aligned by an external magnetic field. This suggests that engineering catalysts into the single-domain regime is one viable path to achieve spin-polarized OER performance without an external magnetic field. However, a significant challenge arises from the fact that many of the most active OER catalysts, such as the oxyhydroxide layers formed during operando surface reconstruction, are not ferromagnetic and thus cannot be directly aligned by a magnetic field. To address this, the spin pinning effect has emerged as a powerful interfacial strategy to extend spin ordering to these non-ferromagnetic active surfaces. This effect is established at the interface between a ferromagnetic material and a non-ferromagnetic material. As demonstrated in the pioneering work by Wu et al., a stable interface can be created between an FM oxide substrate and a reconstructed paramagnetic oxyhydroxide surface layer [106]. Through strong interfacial exchange bias effect, the highly ordered spins within the FM substrate can “pin” the otherwise disordered spins in the thin oxyhydroxide layer, forcing them to become more aligned (Fig. 7f). This induced spin alignment in the catalytically active layer was shown to increase the intrinsic OER activity by approximately an order of magnitude compared to the oxyhydroxide material alone. This concept was further explored using well-defined FM-AFM core–shell nanoparticles (Fe3O4@Ni(OH)2) by Ge et al. [122]. Their work showed that the interfacial coupling acts as a “spin filter” and that the effectiveness of this effect is highly dependent on the shell thickness; a thinner shell allows for stronger interaction between the active surface and the magnetic core, leading to a greater enhancement of OER activity. Overall, the spin pinning effect represents a powerful strategy for engineering spin alignment in catalysts that are not intrinsically ferromagnetic, significantly broadening the scope and potential of spin-related electrocatalysis. 3.6 Magnetothermal effect The magnetothermal effect is a phenomenon in which an AMF generates heat and is commonly observed in specific materials, particularly magnetic nanoparticles [124,125]. As depicted in Fig. 8 a, when these materials are subjected to a varying magnetic field, the interaction and realignment of magnetic particle moments with the external AMF convert electromagnetic energy into thermal energy, thereby heating the reaction system. The temperature of the reaction system plays a pivotal role in electrocatalytic reactions, affecting the activation energy, overpotential, and electrode kinetics [126,127]. The most commonly used equation to describe the relationship between electrocatalytic rate and temperature is the Arrhenius equation [80,128] (5) k = A e x p - E a RT Here, k is the reaction rate constant, A is the pre-exponential factor (or frequency factor), a constant related to collision frequency and reaction geometry, E a is the activation energy (the minimum energy required to initiate the reaction), R is the gas constant, and T is the absolute temperature. In electrocatalytic processes, elevating the temperature reduces the E a of the reaction, thereby accelerating the reaction rate; however, traditional heating methods may cause corrosion and contamination, whereas a magnetic field, as a non-contact external field, enables localized heating. In magnetic field-assisted electrocatalysis, the magnetothermal effect predominantly occurs under an AMF or a rotating magnetic field, where magnetic nanoparticles exhibit a magnetothermal effect associated with Néel relaxation under an AMF [129], a phenomenon not yet observed in static magnetic fields. The deflection of magnetic domains and displacement of domain walls in magnetic materials [123] convert electromagnetic energy into thermal energy, a process linked to changes in the internal energy of the material induced by varying magnetic field conditions. The heating efficiency of magnetic materials can be evaluated using the specific loss power (SLP) [130,131] (6) S L P = μ 0 π χ " ( f ) H 2 f ρ Φ Here, f is the magnetic field frequency, ρ is the nanoparticle density, Φ is the volume fraction, μ 0 is the permeability of free space (4π × 10−7H m−1), χ " ( f ) is the imaginary part of the magnetic susceptibility, and H is the applied magnetic field strength. The SLP value is proportional to the frequency and strength of the applied magnetic field. Increasing the magnetic field strength (H) and frequency (f) enhances the heating efficiency of magnetic materials. Furthermore, adjusting the size, shape, and composition of magnetic materials can optimize their magnetic anisotropy and saturation magnetization, thereby improving SLP and achieving superior heating performance. This is important for improving the heating efficiency of electrocatalytic reactions. Liu et al. [132] employed an AMF to achieve site-specific localized heating of magnetic elements within a metal–organic framework (CoMn-MOF). Unlike conventional thermal annealing processes, AMF-enabled heating at targeted sites effectively suppressed lattice expansion in the material. As illustrated in Fig. 8b, prolonged magnetothermal treatment elevated the temperature of internal magnetic layers to approximately 480 K, while maintaining near-ambient temperatures in adjacent regions. To validate the AMF-induced magnetic structural transition, MFM images of the material were acquired with and without AMF heating. After AMF treatment, the original magnetic domains exhibited significant contraction (Fig. 8c), indicative of spin reconfiguration driven by localized thermal gradients. Concurrently, the overpotential for the OER progressively decreased with extended magnetothermal duration (Fig. 8d), underscoring the efficacy of AMF in modulating both magnetic and catalytic properties. However, sustaining an AMF requires substantial additional energy, and not all energy produced by the AMF acts on the magnetic material, resulting in low magnetothermal efficiency, where energy losses may far exceed the benefits gained from the magnetothermal effect. Therefore, research on the magnetothermal effect should focus on the magnetic anisotropy and saturation magnetization of magnetic materials to realize efficient utilization of magnetic field energy [133]. Additionally, developing more efficient and precise AMF generation devices could facilitate effective conversion of the magnetothermal effect. 3.7 The role and limitations of the magnetoresistance (MR) effect The MR effect—the change in a material's electrical resistance under a magnetic field—offers a straightforward rationale for the magnetic enhancement of the OER. This hypothesis suggests a direct link: the magnetic field reduces the catalyst's intrinsic resistance by aligning spin channels and minimizing electron scattering, which in turn lowers the charge-transfer barrier and boosts apparent activity [135–137]. Indeed, a growing body of evidence supports this viewpoint. Zhang et al. conducted a systematic study of Ni-based catalysts and discovered a strong correlation between the reduced OER overpotential and the measured negative MR, proposing it as a dominant factor [138]. This perspective is corroborated by studies on complex oxides. For instance, Ma et al. observed that the negative MR of CoFe2O4 contributed synergistically with a photothermal effect to enhance charge transfer (Fig. 9 a–c) [136], while Qian et al. concluded that the negative MR in La1− x Sr x MnO3 is a significant contributor alongside spin polarization, highlighting a potential dual-mechanism synergy (Fig. 9d–f) [135]. These studies make a compelling case that, at least in certain systems, the MR effect cannot be ignored. However, a purely MR-based explanation is insufficient, as it is challenged by several key experimental observations. A primary challenge is the pronounced pH-dependency of the magnetic enhancement, as shown in Fig. 9g, h [52,139]. This strong governance by the electrolyte's chemical environment is difficult to reconcile with MR being an intrinsic bulk electronic property. The MR effect cannot explain the absence of magnetic enhancement in low-pH electrolytes. Instead, this pH dependence suggests the rate-determining step involves the deprotonation of surface adsorbates, pointing to a mechanism rooted in surface chemistry rather than bulk resistance, as highlighted by Wu et al. [106]. Furthermore, the selectivity of the magnetic enhancement is highly informative. The fact that the same magnetic field and catalyst often show no enhancement for other electrocatalytic processes that lack a spin-state transition, such as the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) and ethylene glycol oxidation reaction (EGOR) (Fig. 9i), strongly implies that the driving force is not a universal reduction in material resistance [140]. This selectivity points towards a mechanism intrinsically tied to the unique singlet-to-triplet spin transition of the oxygen reaction pathway. Additionally, while not a direct rebuttal, it is worth noting that significant intrinsic MR is often a cryogenic phenomenon, as seen in materials like WTe2, whereas the OER enhancements are observed at room temperature where such effects are typically diminished [141,142]. Although the MR effect can undoubtedly lower a catalyst's resistance, particularly in systems lacking conductive additives, it is unlikely to be the sole or universally dominant mechanism for OER enhancement. 4 Experimental considerations for electrocatalysis under magnetic fields The study of magnetic field-enhanced electrocatalysis is complicated by the coexistence of multiple physical and chemical effects. The interplay of these effects means that experimental results can be highly sensitive to specific testing conditions. Therefore, a careful consideration of experimental design is paramount for decoupling these effects and ensuring the reliability and comparability of findings, allowing for a clear identification of the true origin of any catalytic enhancement. A consensus on best practices begins with the experimental setup itself. The use of an H-type cell is often recommended to physically isolate the working electrode from the counter and reference electrodes, minimizing potential interference [54]. The choice of magnetic source is also critical; electromagnets are generally preferred over permanent magnets due to their superior control over field strength and uniformity [56]. This uniformity should be verified by measuring the field directly at the electrode position with a Hall probe. The recommended testing set-up is depicted in Fig. 10 . Furthermore, a standardized set of experimental procedures is necessary for reliable data. This includes the rigorous application of iR correction to obtain true electrode potentials and the use of non-magnetic substrates to avoid artifacts [143,144]. Moreover, it is critical to ensure that measurements are recorded only after the system has reached a steady state. Comparisons of electrocatalytic performance, for instance, should be made using stabilized CV curves, not the initial, often transient, scans which may reflect surface conditioning or reconstruction rather than a true magnetic field effect [106,122]. With a standardized setup, a foundational aspect of analysis is distinguishing macroscopic mass transport phenomena from intrinsic catalytic activity improvement. The MHD effect can certainly accelerate ion transport and gas bubble detachment, which is particularly significant in mass-transport-limited regimes. However, this is not an enhancement of the catalyst's intrinsic activity. To decouple this, forced convection techniques such as the use of a rotating disk electrode can be employed. Similarly, confounding thermal effects must be rigorously excluded. Rigorous temperature control is essential, as external Joule heating or internal magnetothermal effects can universally accelerate reaction rates according to the Arrhenius equation. For this reason, it is important to monitor the temperature at the electrode surface and use a cooling system if needed. Beyond the general effects of parallel and perpendicular fields, a deeper consideration of magnetic field angular dependencies is crucial, especially for catalysts with specific morphologies like 2D MOFs or LDHs. While many of these materials may not exhibit long-range ferromagnetic order, they possess intrinsic anisotropy stemming from their layered crystal structures or interfacial coupling with ferromagnetic substrates. For spin-related mechanisms, this means their response to a magnetic field is directionally sensitive. Many materials with magnetic anisotropy exhibit a preferred direction of magnetization known as the “easy axis”. To maximize the spin alignment effect, the external magnetic field should be aligned with this easy axis [56]. A misalignment would require a much stronger external field to achieve the same degree of spin polarization, making the angular alignment a critical experimental parameter. Furthermore, catalyst geometry itself directly dictates the spin alignment response. For example, it has been demonstrated that the thickness of a ferromagnetic film determines its magnetic domain structure; thinner films with a higher proportion of spin-disordered domain walls show a much larger OER enhancement upon magnetization compared to thicker, single-domain-like films [53]. From a mass transport perspective, the catalyst geometry—such as roughness and porosity—also determines the effectiveness of MHD-induced convection. It has been shown that convective mixing is more effective on macroscopically rough surfaces (like foams) than on either smooth surfaces or highly porous nanostructured surfaces where the fluid flow becomes more laminar [68]. Therefore, the MHD effect is not a simple consequence of the bulk current direction but is instead highly sensitive to the interplay between the external field's angle and the catalyst's specific micro- and nano-structure. A comprehensive understanding thus requires a multi-scale view that considers these angular and geometric dependencies. 5 Oxygen electrocatalysis enhancement by the magnetic field effect As reviewed in previous sections, magnetic fields can influence oxygen electrocatalysis through several mechanisms that often coexist and jointly determine overall performance. For gas‐evolving reactions such as the OER, two aspects have received primary attention: intrinsic spin‐related effects and the enhancement of bubble detachment by macroscopic forces. At low current densities—where electron‐transfer kinetics are rate‐limiting—the subtle spin‐alignment enhancement tends to dominate. In contrast, at high current densities, mass‐transport limitations arising from O2 bubble adhesion become critical, and magnetic‐field induced Lorentz and Kelvin forces assume a leading role by promoting bubble release. A seminal study demonstrated this force balance: an upward Lorentz force and an outward Kelvin force synergistically overcome buoyancy‐opposing forces to clear bubbles, rendering intrinsic spin effects unobservable under those conditions [145]. Conversely, for the ORR—which is inherently mass‐transport limited—the electrolyte convection driven by the MHD effect provides greater benefit, whereas spin effects are not detected. Thus, to disentangle these contributions, one must tailor experimental design: minimizing transport limitations to probe spin phenomena, or employing high‐current, gas‐evolving conditions to study MHD and Kelvin‐force–mediated enhancements. 5.1 Magnetic field enhancement of the OER 5.1.1 Mass transfer enhancement due to bubble removal During the OER process, as O2 is generated, it initially exists as dissolved oxygen in the solution near the catalyst surface. As the reaction progresses, O2 molecules accumulate near the catalyst surface, leading to a supersaturated state [146,147]. In this supersaturated state, O2 gradually forms bubbles, which detach from the surface and rise to the liquid’s surface due to effects such as surface tension and gas diffusion. The formation and detachment of bubbles play a critical role in the OER. Bubbles not only alter the mode of material transport in the reaction but also may influence the reaction kinetics at the catalyst surface. Bubble accumulation at the electrode surface may hinder reactants (e.g., H2O or OH−) from accessing the surface, resulting in localized concentration polarization and reducing catalytic efficiency [148]. Bubble coverage on the electrode surface and voids caused by bubbles in the bulk electrolyte contribute to ohmic polarization within the reaction system. Specifically, bubble coverage on the electrode surface reduces the effective reaction area [148]. Additionally, the copious bubbles generated during the OER accumulate in the electrolyte, forming voids, with the electrolyte resistance proportional to the void thickness [149,150]. Near the electrode, the Lorentz force drives charged particles in the solution to generate helical motion or vortices along specific directions. This convective effect facilitates the rapid transport of reactants (e.g., H2O or OH−) from the bulk electrolyte to the electrode surface, reducing the diffusion boundary layer within the double layer capacitance (Fig. 11 a) [60]. Furthermore, fluid convection induced by the MHD effect generates shear forces between bubbles and the electrode surface, thereby promoting bubble detachment (Fig. 11b) [151]. Particularly in cases where O2 bubbles are persistent and prone to coalescence, the MHD effect, by enhancing electrolyte flow velocity and turbulence, significantly reduces bubble residence time and increases detachment efficiency, effectively mitigating concentration difference polarization and bubble coverage issues [152,153]. To assess the impact of magnetic fields on the OER, Fukunaka et al. [152] conducted water electrolysis experiments in alkaline and acidic electrolytes. They found that the reduction in overpotential for water electrolysis under a magnetic field is independent of the electrode spacing and spatial configuration. Additionally, they observed that during water electrolysis, the magnetic field’s influence on the OER exceeds that on the HER, as H2 bubbles readily rise and exit the electrolyte as they form, preventing accumulation, whereas O2 bubbles tend to coalesce into larger sizes and adhere to the electrode surface, impeding reactant access to active sites. Consequently, the MHD effect induces a forced convection-like effect in the electrolyte, enabling timely detachment of O2 bubbles from the electrode surface. However, recent studies have revealed that in the OER, where the reactants are solvent-derived species (e.g., H2O or OH− in alkaline electrolytes) and remain abundantly available near the electrode surface, the Grotthuss mechanism dominates the transport of OH− through hydrogen-bond networks in aqueous media [154], as shown in Fig. 11c. Consequently, alterations in electrolyte mass transport induced by external magnetic fields have negligible effects on the reaction current. Although Lorentz force-induced stirring may assist in removing bubbles adhered to the electrode surface, experimental results demonstrate that the overall enhancement in OER current density remains negligible (Fig. 11d–f). For instance, under a constant applied potential, the OER current density increases by only ∼5 %–10 % under a magnetic field, whereas the ORR achieves a significantly higher current improvement of 30 %–51 % under identical conditions. This discrepancy stems from the fact that in the OER, the high concentration and rapid diffusion of reactants (H2O/OH−) prevent the magnetic field-driven mass transport enhancement from substantially overcoming the intrinsic kinetic limitations of the reaction. Conversely, the ability of the Lorentz force to promote bubble detachment is constrained by the surface charge distribution of bubbles and the magnetic field strength, and polarization losses caused by bubble coverage cannot be fully eliminated [54]. Consequently, the magnetic effect of fields on improving mass transport is often weakened or even absent in gas-phase product-dominated reactions such as the OER. Notably, the above conclusions were primarily derived from experiments conducted at low current densities (<20 mA cm−2). In practical high-power devices such as industrial electrolysers and fuel cells, however, the OER process operates at significantly higher current densities (e.g., >100 mA cm−2). Our preliminary experiments demonstrated that RuO2 catalysts supported on porous carbon substrates exhibit pronounced magnetic field-enhanced OER activity at high current densities, whereas this enhancement diminishes at low current densities. This phenomenon suggests that under high-current conditions, bubble accumulation and detachment kinetics are the rate-limiting processes of the reaction, and magnetic fields effectively mitigate these issues by accelerating bubble removal and reducing ohmic resistance. Specifically, the forced convection induced by the Lorentz force becomes critical in disrupting stagnant bubble layers and refreshing active sites under intense gas evolution. These findings further corroborate the importance of magnetic field effects in optimizing mass transport for bubble-driven reactions under industrially relevant high-current regimes. Furthermore, another study directly visualized and quantified the Lorentz force induced by a magnetic field and reported that this force primarily affects ion diffusion to the electrode surface in the electrolyte, with a minimal impact on O2 bubble removal [54]. Thus, although magnetic fields can alter or even accelerate bubble motion direction and trajectories, potentially enhancing electrodeposition rates [155,156], the precise reasons for their impact on bubbles remain unclear, as charges on bubble surfaces may subject them to Lorentz forces induced by the magnetic field [157]. Furthermore, the study suggests that bubbles induce surrounding ion movement during their upwards motion, generating ionic currents that are also influenced by the magnetic field [112]. Therefore, the influence of magnetic fields on O2 warrants reassessment. 5.1.2 Spin polarization-enhanced reaction kinetics During the OER process, the electronic state of O2 transitions from the singlet state of H2O or OH− to a triplet state, necessitating the overcoming of spin conservation constraints [50,158,159]. The influence of magnetic field-induced spin selectivity on electrocatalytic processes has emerged as a central research focus in the field of electrocatalysis in recent years. This effect modulates the spin states of reaction intermediates and products, significantly altering the kinetic and thermodynamic pathways of the reaction. Studies indicate that an external magnetic field can facilitate electron spin flipping of surface adsorbates via spin–orbit coupling, thereby reducing the reaction’s energy barrier and enhancing catalytic activity [109]. For instance, applying an external magnetic field can enhance spin electron exchange between the catalyst and oxygen-containing intermediates, promoting O2 molecule formation. Furthermore, magnetic fields can optimize the adsorption and desorption behaviour of reactants by modifying the catalyst’s electronic structure, further improving catalytic efficiency. Galán-Mascarós et al. [52] systematically demonstrated that magnetic field-induced spin polarization optimizes electron spin alignment, reducing the energy barrier of the OER and significantly enhancing catalytic efficiency. They prepared a variety of electrocatalysts with distinct magnetic properties to investigate the OER performance under magnetic field conditions. They found that the electrocatalytic enhancement effect of magnetic fields is most pronounced for strongly magnetic materials (e.g., NiFe2O X ), which display up to a 150 % improvement, but negligible for non-magnetic catalysts such as IrO2, as shown in Fig. 12 a. They also demonstrated that magnetic fields optimize the OER reaction pathway in alkaline electrolytes, favouring the production of O2 over H2O2 to a greater extent. The researchers propose that the enhanced electrocatalytic activity in magnetic fields arises from the reorientation of local spins at adjacent metal sites from antiparallel to parallel alignment (Fig. 12b), facilitating the formation of triplet O2, thus making this effect most significant for strongly magnetic materials. This work represents a pioneering study on the enhancement of OER electrocatalysis by magnetic fields, and the findings encourage further in-depth exploration of the origins of magnetic field-induced OER enhancement. Ren et al. [140] investigated the OER electrocatalytic performance of three catalysts with distinct magnetic properties under magnetic field conditions. They posited that the OER process in alkaline or acidic electrolytes is unaffected by the Lorentz force, attributing this independence to the continuous proton hopping (Grotthuss mechanism) of OH− and H3O+ in aqueous solution [154,160–162]. Furthermore, no influence of the Lorentz force on mass transport or bubble removal was observed in antiferromagnetic and non-magnetic materials, ruling out the MHD effect in the OER electrocatalytic process. They further explored the dynamics of electron spin polarization during the electrocatalytic process. Tafel analysis revealed that the magnetic field shifts the rate-determining step from the first electron transfer step to both the first and second electron transfer steps (Fig. 12c). Mechanistically, under a sufficiently strong magnetic field, the magnetic moment direction of ferromagnetic materials aligns with the field, enhancing 3d-2p orbital hybridization; this process acts as a spin-selective filter in the OER process, facilitating predominant ferromagnetic exchange between the ferromagnetic catalyst and adsorbed oxygen species (reactants) (Fig. 12d) and reducing the overpotential for triplet O2 formation by 390 mV (Fig. 12e). Studies on the catalytic effects of magnetic fields on the MOR and EGOR, they suggested that magnetic field effects predominantly influence reactions involving electron spin polarization (Fig. 12f), with less pronounced effects on reactions where reactants, intermediates, and products are diamagnetic (Fig. 12g). Notably, the OER electrocatalytic performance of ferromagnetic materials remains unaffected after magnetic field removal, reverting to pre-field levels upon demagnetization and further excluding other magnetic field effects. Subsequently, Xu et al. [53] demonstrated that enhancement of the OER in magnetic fields originates from the disappearance of domain walls in ferromagnetic materials, with a strong correlation between the domain wall area and increase in OER current. Although numerous studies suggest that the electronic configuration of ferromagnetic materials, such as metal cation spin states or electron spin directions, remains unchanged upon magnetic field application, this lack of an effect is attributed to the fact that typical magnetic field strengths of a few hundred mT are insufficient to induce the required changes in electron spin configuration [113]. However, this explanation is still debated, as Xue et al. [38] demonstrated that an AMF can induce a transition in the metal sites of magnetic materials from low- to high-spin states, optimizing the adsorption–desorption rates of oxygen-containing intermediates during the reaction and realizing exceptionally high OER electrocatalytic activity with an overpotential of only 179 mV at a current density of 100 mA cm−2. Additionally, Yu et al. [85] anchored CoPc onto polymer-coated magnetic nanoparticles to produce a magnetic electrocatalyst with an inherent magnetic field. Through this intrinsic magnetic field, the Co active centre transitioned from a low to a high spin state, increasing the Co electron spin magnetic moment from 0.153 µB to 0.653 µB and thereby facilitating spin transitions of oxygen intermediates during the OER process. Wang et al. [163] modulated the electron spin state of Fe–N–C from low to intermediate and even high spin states through synergistic crystal field and magnetic field interactions. Non-bonding interactions between Cu–N–C and Fe–N–C induced a spin transition from low-spin Fe(II) to intermediate-spin Fe(III), with the proportion of high-spin Fe(III) increasing upon full polarization under a strong magnetic field. Furthermore, density functional theory (DFT) calculations provided evidence supporting the aforementioned spin configuration transitions. The experimental results revealed that catalysts with high-spin states exhibit significantly lower OER electrocatalytic overpotentials than those with low- and intermediate-spin states. Wang et al. [164] investigated the use of Ni3Fe/charcoal (Ni3Fe-CW) electrodes for efficient water splitting with magnetic field assistance. Metal ions were introduced into wood channels via a hydrothermal method, followed by high-temperature carbonization to form uniformly distributed Ni3Fe nanoparticles, which exhibited both electrocatalytic and magnetic activity. The study revealed that, under a 300 mT magnetic field, Ni3Fe-CW achieved an OER overpotential of 237 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, demonstrating a significant enhancement in catalytic activity. The DFT calculations indicated that the magnetic field enhances Ni3Fe spin polarization, accelerates electron transfer, reduces the reaction energy barrier, and improves catalytic efficiency. Given the highly complex compositional and structure of magnetic alloys or ferrites, studying the metal spin states of the active sites in these materials remains challenging. In contrast, magnetic single-atom catalysts serve as an ideal experimental model for exploring how active site spin states enhance OER activity. Single-atom catalysts, with their uniformly distributed active sites, enable highly precise control over spin states. This allows researchers to precisely observe and interpret the specific effects of spin states on catalytic activity. The metal centres in single-atom catalysts can be readily tuned via external magnetic fields or chemical modification, facilitating the study of their catalytic behaviour under various spin configurations. Li et al. [165] applied a Co single-atom catalyst (Co1/TaS2) in the OER and examined the impact of spin density modulation on OER activity. The research team modulated the spin density of adjacent Co sites by varying the Co loading. The experimental and theoretical results demonstrated that optimizing the spin density of Co sites significantly enhances OER performance. By adjusting the spin exchange interactions of neighbouring Co sites, the study elucidated the correlation between active site spin states and OER activity, offering new strategies for designing efficient magnetic single-atom catalysts. Overall, the enhancement of the OER by magnetic fields primarily stems from electron spin modulation, although this explanation remains subject to some controversy [166]. Theoretically, magnetic fields can only alter the domain structure of materials without changing the spin direction of unpaired electrons; however, since spin polarization is inherent within the internal domain structure, additional magnetic field application may not be necessary; thus, further direct evidence is required to attribute OER enhancement to electron spin modulation alone. In recent years, some researchers have attributed magnetic field-induced enhancement to the disappearance of domain walls [53], a hypothesis with considerable plausibility. 5.1.3 Acceleration of reaction rates via the magnetothermal effect The magnetothermal effect significantly enhances the OER, primarily by elevating local temperatures during the electrochemical process (Fig. 13 a, b). According to the Arrhenius equation, reaction rates are closely related to temperature, with an increase in temperature effectively reducing the activation energy of chemical reactions, thereby accelerating the reaction process [167]. Niether et al. [51] were the first to utilize nickel-coated iron carbide nanoparticles (FeC–Ni), which exhibit pronounced magnetothermal properties under a high-frequency AMF. As shown in Fig. 13c, localized magnetic heating significantly reduces the OER overpotential, with a reduction of approximately 200 mV at a current density of 20 mA cm−2, equivalent to an apparent increase in the reaction system temperature of approximately 200 °C, while the actual electrolyser temperature increases by only 5 °C. Without a magnetic field, the OER occurs at 2.12 V, with potential noise arising from bubble-induced transient overpotentials (Fig. 13d). The application of an AMF induces an immediate reduction in overpotential (ΔE = 90–210 mV), which scales with field strength (24.3–48 mT). The iR-corrected potential reaches 1.6 V at 18 mA cm−2 (48 mT), positioning FeC–Ni/C among the top-tier OER catalysts (Fig. 13e, f). This approach enables the attainment of near-theoretical overpotentials for water splitting even at ambient temperatures, a feat challenging to achieve with conventional water electrolysis techniques. Peng et al. [134] prepared NiFe/NiFeOOH core–shell nanoparticles via an electrochemical reconstruction strategy and evaluated their OER performance under AMF stimulation. The study demonstrated that these superparamagnetic core–shell nanoparticles significantly enhance OER activity under an AMF through a Néel relaxation-related magnetothermal effect. This approach yielded nanoparticles with a low overpotential and excellent catalytic stability, which was attributed primarily to the highly conductive confined structure and efficient charge transfer. Zhou et al. [132] investigated strategies to enhance OER efficiency through AMF-induced spin state reconstruction. They utilized metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), specifically Co– and Mn-doped bimetallic MOFs, as thermally differentiated spin-electronic catalysts. Under an AMF, these materials enable localized magnetic heating, promoting electron spin flipping and reconstruction at specific active sites, significantly enhancing OER catalytic activity (Fig. 13g, h). Through this method, the researchers demonstrated how magnetic field stimulation modulates spin states (Fig. 13i) and how these spin state changes influence orbital interactions between the catalyst and intermediates, thereby optimizing OER performance. In the magnetothermal effect, an applied AMF induces rapid heating of magnetic materials (e.g., magnetic nanoparticles) via a localized and concentrated effect that elevates the reaction zone temperature without increasing the overall system temperature. This precisely controlled localized heating not only enhances the OER but also reduces overall energy consumption, and potentially improves the stability and durability of the electrocatalyst. 5.1.4 Reaction kinetics enhancement induced by domain wall flipping In paramagnetic and ferromagnetic catalysts, internal atomic magnetic moments are randomly oriented without an external magnetic field; upon application of an external field, the domains realign, and the domain walls shift, resulting in the alignment of more domains with the field direction. This process, termed domain motion, ultimately results in the material exhibiting macroscopic magnetism [168,169]. When the external magnetic field is sufficiently strong, the material reaches a saturated magnetization state, with all domain magnetic moments aligned in parallel [46]. To gain deeper insight into how magnetic fields affect multi-domain ferromagnetic catalysts, the behaviour of ferromagnetic catalysts in promoting the spin-polarized OER under an external magnetic field was examined. Ge et al. [139] demonstrated that single-domain ferromagnetic catalysts, even without an external magnetic field, exhibit OER enhancement effects comparable to those of magnetized multi-domain ferromagnetic catalysts (Fig. 14 a). This is because the spin configuration of single-domain catalysts is already ordered in the absence of an applied magnetic field, enabling them to achieve an enhancement effect comparable to that of multi-domain catalysts under no-magnetic-field conditions (Fig. 14b). The experimental results revealed that the OER performance of single-domain catalysts was significantly improved (Fig. 14c), confirming that an external magnetic field is not a prerequisite for achieving spin-polarized enhancement in ferromagnetic catalysts. This finding simplifies the application of electron spin polarization, allowing the direct use of single-domain ferromagnetic catalysts in electrolysers without the need for additional magnetic field equipment. To elucidate the mechanism by which magnetic fields enhance the OER activity of multi-domain catalysts, Ren et al. [53] prepared materials with varying domain thicknesses (Fig. 14d, e) and investigated the impact of magnetic fields on the OER performance of NiFe thin-film electrodes with controlled domain walls (Fig. 14f), revealing the origin of the reason for the promotion of OER catalytic activity by magnetization. The study revealed that the enhancement effect of magnetization does not stem from spin polarization of unpaired electrons within the magnetic material, but rather from the disappearance of domain walls. Analysis of NiFe thin films showed that magnetization transforms the domain structure from a multi-domain to single-domain configuration, eliminating domain walls in the process and converting areas on the surface that were previously occupied by domain walls into single-domain regions (Fig. 14g); this change facilitates the OER reaction along a spin-assisted pathway, thereby enhancing the overall catalytic activity. Consequently, NiFe-200, with the largest domain wall area, exhibited the greatest OER enhancement, while NiFe-800, with the smallest domain wall area, showed the least enhancement (Fig. 14h). Thus, the proportion of domain interfaces is a critical structural parameter determining the magnetoelectric coupling effect. It is worth noting that the enhancement from this domain wall elimination effect is highly dependent on the specific OER pathway. Theoretical work suggests that this mechanism has a minimal impact on reactions proceeding via the adsorbent evolution mechanism (AEM) or the lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM). Instead, it most significantly benefits the intermolecular mechanism (I2M) [170]. This is because when the magnetic field eliminates the spin-disordered domain walls, the adjacent coordinated oxygen atoms on the newly formed single-domain active sites can readily couple via a low-barrier, spin-polarized pathway, as shown in Fig. 14i. However, the aforementioned mechanism primarily applies to catalysts that are themselves ferromagnetic, which leads to a significant challenge: many of the most active OER catalysts, such as the oxyhydroxide layers formed during operando surface reconstruction, are not ferromagnetic and thus cannot be directly aligned by a magnetic field. To overcome this, the spin pinning effect has emerged as a powerful interfacial strategy to extend spin ordering to these non-ferromagnetic active surfaces [106,122,170]. This effect, often arising from exchange bias at the interface between a ferromagnetic underlayer and the non-ferromagnetic active layer, allows the highly ordered spins within the substrate to “pin” the otherwise disordered spins in the catalytically active material, forcing them to become more aligned, as shown in Fig. 14j.
